name: Black Diamond
note: Believed to be the largest Indian elephant in captivity.

name: Isilo
note: One of South Africa’s largest Africans and the largest living tusker (a male elephant with tusks weighing over 100 pounds) in the southern hemisphere before his death.

name: Mona
note: Thought, at 60, to have been the oldest Asian in the United States.

name: Tai
note: Known for featuring in the films Larger than Life and Water for Elephants.

name: John L. Sullivan
note: A boxing elephant in Adam Forepaugh's circus.

name: Abul-Abbas
note: An elephant given to Carolingian emperor Charlemagne by the Abbasid caliph Harun al-Rashid.

name: Lin Wang
note: Served with the Chinese Expeditionary Force during the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937–1945) and later relocated to Taiwan with the Kuomintang forces.

name: The Cremona Elephant
note: A gift presented to Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II by Sultan of Egypt Al-Kamil, in 1229. Frederick used the elephant in his triumph parades.

name: Fanny
note: A female elephant who spent the majority of her life in a small zoo.

name: Kashin
note: Famous for being sponsored by ASB Bank, and featured in the New Zealand produced television programme The Zoo.

name: Suleiman
note: Presented in 1551 to Maximilian II, the Holy Roman Emperor, by John III, the King of Portugal, and named after the Ottoman Sultan, Suleiman the Magnificent.

name: Tuffi
note: A female circus elephant that became famous in Germany during 1950 when she accidentally fell into the River Wupper, and survived.

name: Hattie
note: An elephant in New York City's Central Park Zoo that was described as the "most intelligent of all elephants" and "nearly human."

name: Hanno
note: The pet white elephant given by King Manuel I of Portugal to Pope Leo X at his coronation.

name: Arjuna
note: A lead elephant of the world-famous Mysore Dasara procession.

name: Surus
note: Mentioned as the bravest of Hannibal's 37 war elephants which crossed the Alps in 218 BC during the Second Punic War, by Cato the Elder in his book Origines.

name: Drona
note: The lead Dasara Elephants of the Jamboo Savari of Mysore Dasara. He carried the Golden Howdah for a record 18 years consecutive years between 1981 and 1997, before being electrocuted while grazing in 1998.

name: Raja Gaj
note: Considered to be the world's largest Asian of modern times.

name: Kolakolli
note: An Indian rogue elephant which gained considerable notoriety among Indian media and was accused of killing 12 people in and around Peppara over a span of seven to eight years.

name: Ziggy
note: After attacking and nearly killing his keeper, Ziggy was chained to the wall of an indoor enclosure, and remained there for nearly three decades. In the late 1960s, when school children and other animal enthusiasts began campaigning for his release, eventually winning the case.

name: Lallah Rookh
note: A female elephant known for her tightrope walking act.

name: Queenie
note: Gave rides for children at Melbourne Zoo for 40 years.

name: Sauce
note: Salt and Sauce were once two of Britain's most famous and notorious performing elephants. Sauce killed her owner and trainer in an accident at Walthamstow Station and Salt killed an elephant groom when she attacked him in 1957 on Rosaire's Circus.

name: Salt
note: Salt and Sauce were once two of Britain's most famous and notorious performing elephants. Sauce killed her owner and trainer in an accident at Walthamstow Station and Salt killed an elephant groom when she attacked him in 1957 on Rosaire's Circus.

name: Mary
note: Also known as "Mighty Mary" and "Murderous Mary", this circus elephant was was hanged by a railroad derrick car after killing her inexperienced keeper. This is the only known elephant hanging in history.
